pullRequest.body:
This is the first part of the refactor of algebraic filter bases discussed [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Refactoring.20algebraic.20filter.20bases/near/479437345). This adds the new APIs without touching any existing file in order to split the work. **Please review this by comparing with the existing API!**

See #18202 for the full picture.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ecfc7661ff](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18437/commits/ecfc7661ffc47980e00f5e20d039b2550298be42)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.FilterBasisNew` (new file)|1088|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Nonarchimedean.BasesNew` (new file)|1096|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ HasBasis.isGroupBasis`
`+ HasBasis.isModuleBasis`
`+ HasBasis.isRingBasis`
`+ IsAddGroupBasis`
`+ IsGroupBasis`
`+ IsGroupBasis.mk_of_comm`
`+ IsModuleBasis`
`+ IsModuleBasis.mk_of_hasBasis`
`+ IsRingBasis`
`+ IsRingBasis.mk_of_comm`
`+ continuousSMul_of_hasBasis`
`+ instance (priority := 100) continuousConstSMul :`
`+ instance (priority := 100) continuousSMul [TopologicalRing R] :`
`+ instance (priority := 100) topologicalGroup :`
`+ instance (priority := 100) topologicalRing :`
`+ mem_nhds_one`
`+ mk_of_ideals_of_comm`
`+ mk_of_submodules`
`+ mk_of_submodules_of_hasBasis`
`+ nhds_eq`
`+ nhds_hasBasis`
`+ nhds_one_eq`
`+ nhds_one_hasBasis`
`+ openSubgroup_of_subgroups`
`+ topologicalGroup_of_hasBasis`
`+ topologicalRing_of_hasBasis`
`+ topology'`
`++ mk_of_subgroups`
`++ mk_of_subgroups_of_comm`
`++ nonarchimedean_of_subgroups`
`+++ topology`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Increase in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (1.00, 0.00)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|5012|1|porting notes|

Current commit [ecfc7661ff](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/ecfc7661ffc47980e00f5e20d039b2550298be42)
Reference commit [675c28ea28](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/675c28ea285896bbe83cb32f8a0bca7e481be614)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
As far as I can tell, `IsBasis` is not a `class`; so I don't think this should be either.
You are completely right.
I'd be tempted to drop this `def` and inline it into the `HasBasis` statement.
left translation, right translation ? Does it matter ?
I wouldn't say that this is mathematically the same thing.
I have the impression that it is preferred to include `hB` explicitly in all relevant lemmas. (Several other occurrences below)
What about monoid topologies?

Well, monoid topologies are not described by their neighborhood filter at a single point... For example, for the additive monoid of nonnegative reals, the usual topology is a monoid topology, and so is (I believe) the topology generated by all `[a, b[` intervals. These two topologies are definitely distinct, but they have the same neighborhood filter at the origin.

I guess it would still make sense to write down the basis version of [ContinuousAdd.of_nhds_zero](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Monoid.html#ContinuousAdd.of_nhds_zero), but it sounds a bit weird to me precisely because the hypotheses of that theorem are not true for any topological monoid (e.g not in `NNReal` with its usual topology)
I have no way to assess the relevance of this priority level. Why 100, why not 200 or 50?

Most instances of `ContinuousConstSMul` have the default priority of 1000, so anything lower will just be considered later. Here, that's because we don't want Lean to spend ages trying to unify the topology on G with a topology of this exact form. Instead, any user defining a topology in this way should repeat the instance (with usual priority) in that special setting. As for 100/200/50, the truth is it probably doesn't matter because there's not that many instances of `ContinuousConstSMul` to consider in the hierarchy. What matters is that it's below 1000.
Shouldn't there be constructor that starts from scratch and takes care of commutativity of addition? Maybe not

This is a matter of taste. The nice thing with this approach is that it gives you full freedom on how you prove `IsAddGroupBasis`: it can be via the commutative constructor, or because you already have a TopologicalAddGroup instance, or anything that we might add in the future. A more unfolded constructor is certainly possible, but I'm not sure it really brings anything.
What is the obstruction to such a lemma?
Mostly that I was lazy to think of the proper API and find the correct file to put this in, so I just stuck to something like the current API...

The docstring is quite detailed but it might be enhanced by two or three baby case examples that show how to use it in practice. Possibly a link to the relevant mathlib files is enough, in which case this could be done afterwards, once this file has became the canonical API.
Yes, I think that linking a posteriori to other files is the best approach. I may rewrite the "usage indications" a bit though.
maybe `mul_subset` would be a better name.
maybe `mul_subset` would be a better name.
Can you please add docstrings to each field ? Maybe the linter will request that anyway

pullRequest.title: refactor: add refactored APIs for algebraic filter bases

source.title: refactor: adapt `KrullTopology` to the new algebraic filter bases API
refactor: use new algebraic filter bases API in `FiniteAdeleRing`
refactor(AdicTopology): use new API for algebraic filter bases, and factor some code
[Merged by Bors] - feat: definition of linear topologies
